title: R Markdown Introduction
description: Understanding Basics of R Markdown (RMD) Tutorial
contents:
Contents
What is R
Markdown?
R Markdown
View

What is R Markdown?
It is an authoring framework for data-based projects. R Markdown is
also referred to as “RMD”. It is used to connect the data and generate
reports. RMD is a simple plain text file with three types of
content:
YAML metadata to guide the RMD process
Code Chunks to run
Text to display
R Markdown View


Show code

knitr::include_graphics(path = "G:/TA/image/RMD.png")




RMD can be used in the R Interactive Development Environment (IDE)
for productive notebook interface. RMD files are stored as “.RMD” . To
build a report from the RMD file, “knit” function can be used to render
a report. RMD renders the report in familiar formats running the code
and embedding the results in the finished document. RMD builds many
familiar formats, such as:
HTML
PDF
Word Doc
Slide Show
Dashboards & many more…
In every case RMD remains as a reproducible record of work easy to
track in version control system like Git and easy to deploy in
future.

title: Importing Datasets from Github
description: How to import datasets from web repository..
contents:
Contents
What is
Github?
How to import datasets from
Github?

What is Github?
At a high level, GitHub is a website and cloud-based service that
helps developers store and manage their code, as well as track and
control changes to their code. To understand exactly what GitHub is, you
need to know two connected principles: - Version control - Git
What is Version Control?
Version control helps developers track and manage changes to a
software project’s code. As a software project grows, version control
becomes essential. Version control lets developers safely work through
branching and merging. With branching, you can duplicate part of the
source code (called the repository) and then safely
make changes to that part of the code without affecting the rest of the
project. Then, once you get your part of the code working properly, you
can merge that code back into the main source code to make it official.
All of these changes are then tracked and can be reverted if need
be.
What is Git?
Git is a specific open-source version control system created by Linus
Torvalds in 2005. Specifically, Git is a distributed version control
system, which means that the entire codebase and history is available on
your computer, which allows for easy branching and merging. Essentially,
it makes it a lot easier for individuals and teams to use Git for
version control and collaboration.
Now that we understand what is Git and Github, we can use it as a
repository to host data sets and directly import data sets from there to
RStudio for executing the projects.
How to import datasets from
Github?
For the purpose of the DACSS 601 course work, all the relevant
datasets for classwork have been hosted in Github in the repo
DACSS-601-SUMMER-2022-BLOGS. This repo has a file
datasets with two sub files:


Show code

knitr::include_graphics(path = "F:/DACSS-601-SUMMER-2022-BLOGS/image/gitrepoaddress.png")




This repo has a file datasets with two sub-files: -
Advanced_Uncleaned Datasets -
basic Datasets
You can use any of the sub-files to access the data sets. There are
different types of data sets available with various difficulty levels.
Please chose a data set with your level of comfort and import the same
to R Studio to Github.


Show code

knitr::include_graphics(path = "F:/DACSS-601-SUMMER-2022-BLOGS/image/gitrepodatasetsubfile.png")




So let us import a data set from basic datasets
sub-file.


Show code

knitr::include_graphics(path = "F:/DACSS-601-SUMMER-2022-BLOGS/image/gitreposubfilebasicdatasets.png")




Let us now import poultry_tidy.csv to RStudio. In order
to import the data set from Github repo, we should be careful of
importing it from RAWcontent only. To access the
RAW content data, you need to select the concerned data set
by clicking on it first. That will take you to the data set
page in Github.


Show code

knitr::include_graphics(path = "F:/DACSS-601-SUMMER-2022-BLOGS/image/gitreposubfilebasicdatasetsrawcontentlink.png")




Now, select the RAW tab highlighted in the above image
to access the raw content data else the data will always default to
html type and will not get imported properly in
RStudio.


Show code

knitr::include_graphics(path = "F:/DACSS-601-SUMMER-2022-BLOGS/image/gitreposubfilebasicdatasetsrawcontentdata.png")




You can now copy the url and use it to import the data
set as shown in the code chunk below:


Show code

# invoke package readr
library(readr)

#import poultry dataset
poultry <- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/abhinavkr26/DACSS-601-SUMMER-2022-BLOGS/main/datasets/basic%20datasets/poultry_tidy.csv")

head(poultry)


# A tibble: 6 × 4
  Product  Year Month    Price_Dollar
  <chr>   <dbl> <chr>           <dbl>
1 Whole    2013 January          2.38
2 Whole    2013 February         2.38
3 Whole    2013 March            2.38
4 Whole    2013 April            2.38
5 Whole    2013 May              2.38
6 Whole    2013 June             2.38

Now, here we can observe that we have directly imported the dataset
from Github without downloading or cloning the repository locally in our
system. This is critical skill in our toolset as we may not always be
able to download or clone repositiores in our local system. Also, it
takes substantial space in our local system. However, if there is a need
to download or clone the datasets then it can be done easily and then
the datasets can easily be imported to R Studio from the local system
itself. We will cover that in the next blog.
Now, please do try to import the other datasets from the datasets
repository on your own to practice. For any errors that you are unable
to resolve, please reach out to the course teaching assistanct or the
faculty. Although, it is highly recomended that you look for the
solution to the error online on platforms such as
Stack Overflow for a better understanding and mitigate such
issues in future on your own.
